awd_titl_txt: CyberTraining: CIP: North Central Region Cyber Training Center for Cybersecurity at Dakota State University
awd_abstract_narration:
The gap between necessary cybersecurity skills and the demands placed on cybersecurity professionals is a challenge for the scientific research enterprise of the nation.  This project will create a scalable online training program and develop specific training materials in cybersecurity for the advanced scientific cyberinfrastructure to address the skillset gap.  Investigators will collaborate with their academic and industry partners to identify cybersecurity skill gaps specifically for advanced scientific cyberinfrastructure and to develop corresponding training materials for the online program.  The project will engage a wide ranging audience from the scientific research community and help them develop and expand their expertise in cybersecurity for advanced scientific cyberinfrastructure.  Thus, as stated by NSF's mission, the project serves the national interest to promote the progress of science; to advance national; and to secure the national defense.

The project will establish a North Central Region (NCR) Cyber Training Center (CTC) for cybersecurity at Dakota State University.  The goal of CTC is to create a scalable online cyber training program to assist with the workforce development of scientific cyberinfrastructure professionals in cybersecurity.  The target participants of the online training program include post-docs, research scientists and faculty researchers and educators from 2-year and 4-year colleges, as well as undergraduate and graduate students who want to develop specialty in cybersecurity within the NCR and beyond.  The CyberTraining Professionals program is included in the project to increase the impact of the program and establish a joint task force with industry to address the cybersecurity skills gap challenge.  Highlights of this online training program are cutting-edge cybersecurity curriculum and hands-on labs and assignments to promote and support the rich learning environment. A new online training web site and an AWS Cybersecurity Lab will be created in the project to facilitate the training activities.  The project will also develop specific training materials which are relevant to advanced scientific cyberinfrastructure and provided online for public access.  Examples of the training materials to be included in this program include modules on compliance issues, identity management on different campuses, science DMZ, and Internet of Things.  The CTC program will bring unique learning experiences to the project participants.  Dakota State University will leverage its NSA designation as a Center of Academic Excellence in Research (CAE-R) and the already developed and functioning Information Security Research and Education consortium (INSuRE) to further promote and expand scientific research in the cyber world.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The project established a North Central Region (NCR) Cyber Training Center (CTC) for cybersecurity at Dakota State University. The Cyber Training Center aimed to create a scalable online cyber training program to assist with the workforce development of scientific cyberinfrastructure professionals in cybersecurity. Three training opportunities have been enabled in this project: 1) CyberTraining Faculty Program targeted faculty in 2-year and 4-year colleges in the North Central Region. 2) CyberTraining Students Program targeted students in the nation who have interests in cybersecurity. 3) CyberTraining Professionals Program targeted professionals who develop, deploy, manage, and support cybersecurity in the information technology sector.

The main outcomes of the project include: (1) The project established an innovative, scalable, and informal training model for cybersecurity workforce development. This project utilized DSU’s online program to provide cybersecurity summer courses for faculty across the nation. A training website was built to host the developed cybersecurity curriculum. It was made publicly available for both students and professionals during the project time period. The project also identifies practical ways to host virtual cybersecurity labs using Amazon Web Service to provide hands-on trainings for undergraduate and graduate students. (2) This project helped develop a highly skilled workforce including faculty, students, and professional staff in cybersecurity. Through the CyberTraining Faculty program, there have been 315 faculty members who participated in 13 cybersecurity courses in the summer between 2017 and 2021. Among the 315 faculty participants, 87 of the faculty participants were female. The faculty participants gained substantial skills in cybersecurity from the offered graduate courses and were able to apply what they learned from these courses to their own. The project supported 19 cybersecurity curriculum development. Many of these developed cybersecurity courses have become an important part of the academic programs in the participants’ home institutions. The project was also able to support 12 cybersecurity workshops across the nation. The cybersecurity workshops were hosted either online or on-campus at the participants’ home institutions. Many K-12, undergraduate, and graduate students have benefited from these workshops. (3) This project worked closely with the National Center of Academic Excellence (CAE) in Cybersecurity Community to promote the training program and established the initial contacts with the institutions in the North Central Region. The collaborations among the project team and the faculty participants of the project will continue beyond of the project. The joined efforts in workforce development from these collaborations will help reduce and close cybersecurity skills gap. The impact of this project on teaching and educational experiences will last long time. More students and institutions will benefit from the project.

 


Last Modified: 12/20/2021
Modified by: Yong Wang
